easy.text: Did Jesus ever directly call Himself 'God' in the Gospels?
easy.explanation: While Jesus implied divinity through 'I AM' statements and accepting worship, He never explicitly said 'I am God' in the canonical Gospels.

easy.text: Paul's command for women to 'keep silent' in church (1 Corinthians 14) ‚Äî was it universal or situational?
easy.explanation: Most scholars interpret this as addressing specific disorderly conduct in the Corinthian church, not a universal prohibition.

easy.text: 'Faith without works is dead' (James 2) ‚Äî does this contradict Paul?
easy.explanation: James and Paul address different aspects: Paul emphasizes justification before God, James emphasizes evidence of genuine faith.

easy.text: Did Jesus promise His followers an easy life of comfort?
easy.explanation: Jesus promised persecution and hardship for His followers, not comfort and ease.
While given to the apostles, the commission extends to all believers throughout history.

medium.text: Which council established the doctrine of the Trinity?
medium.explanation: The Council of Nicaea (325) established the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, laying groundwork for Trinitarian doctrine.

medium.text: What is the proper relationship between Scripture and Tradition?
medium.explanation: The Council of Trent affirmed that Scripture and Tradition together form the deposit of faith, not in opposition but in harmony.

medium.text: How many natures does Christ have according to the Chalcedonian Definition?
medium.explanation: The Council of Chalcedon (451) defined that Christ has two natures, divine and human, united in one person.

hard.text: What was the primary issue addressed by the Council of Ephesus?
hard.explanation: The Council of Ephesus (431) affirmed Mary as Theotokos against Nestorius, who preferred Christotokos.

hard.text: Which heresy taught that Jesus was purely divine and only appeared to be human?
hard.explanation: Docetism taught that Christ only appeared to have a physical body, denying His true humanity.

expert.text: What was the theological significance of the filioque controversy?

options.text: The Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father only
The Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and the Son
The Holy Spirit is subordinate to the Son
The Holy Spirit is not divine

expert.explanation: The filioque ('and the Son') controversy centered on whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father alone or from both Father and Son.

Nicaea.name: Council of Nicaea
Nicaea.description: First ecumenical council, established the divinity of Christ

Constantinople.name: Council of Constantinople
Constantinople.description: Refined and expanded the Nicene Creed

Chalcedon.name: Council of Chalcedon
Chalcedon.description: Defined Christ's two natures (divine and human)
